Tabs component

A tabbed interface component is a set of layered areas, known as tab panels, where only one area is displayed at a time [...]

The user should be able to activate a tab at a time with keyboard or mouse interactions revealing only the content he/she is interested in.

Keyboard interactions

The user should be able to reach the active tab component (ie the header) by pressing TAB following the regular source flow.

Once the tab interface is reached, if the user press TAB again, the focus will be send to the next focusable element within the active tabpanel until there is not more focusable element so that the focus leaves the component.

When the focus is on the tab headers, the user can use the different arrow keys to switch the active tab.

Progressive enhancement strategy

In this strategy we are going to progressively enhance our tab component so it would keep working without javascript while still conveying meaningful semantic and providing relevant keyboard interaction.

Note: you should be able to interact with the resulting tab component with Javascript disabled.

First step: creating a tab component css powered using native html5 elements

We use visually hidden (but not hidden for assistive user agents) inputs type radio to provide keyboard interactions. A combination of flexbox properties and sibling selectors then give us the visual aspect expected fo such component.

We also add the recommended aria roles so assistive technologies such voice over manages to give more accurate semantic to the user.

  • Markup
  • Style

index.html


<div id="progressive-tabs" role="tablist">
  <input class="visuallyhidden" id="progressive-tab1" aria-controls="progressive-panel1" role="tab" type="radio" name="progressive-tabs"/>
  <label for="progressive-tab1">Section 1</label>
  <section id="progressive-panel1" role="tabpanel">
    <h3>header for section 1</h3>
    <p>this is a paragraph</p>
  </section>
  <input class="visuallyhidden" id="progressive-tab2" aria-controls="progressive-panel2" checked="checked" role="tab" type="radio" name="progressive-tabs"/>
  <label for="progressive-tab2">Section two</label>
  <section id="progressive-panel2" role="tabpanel">
    <h3>Header for section two</h3>
    <p>this is a paragraph for 2</p>
  </section>
  <input class="visuallyhidden" id="progressive-tab3" aria-controls="progressive-panel3" role="tab" type="radio" name="progressive-tabs"/>
  <label for="progressive-tab3">Section three</label>
  <section id="progressive-panel3" role="tabpanel">
    <h3>Header for section three</h3>
    <p>this is a paragraph for 3</p>
  </section>
</div>

we can set the attribute checked to use a different default active tab

theme.css

/* utility class to hide visually content */
.visuallyhidden {
    position: absolute;
    overflow: hidden;
    clip: rect(0 0 0 0);
    height: 1px;
    width: 1px;
    margin: -1px;
    padding: 0;
    border: 0;
}

#progressive-tabs[role=tablist] {
    display: flex;
    flex-wrap: wrap;
}

/* the tab headers: we make them first in the flex order */
#progressive-tabs label {
    flex-grow: 1;
    order: 1;
    text-align: center;
    padding: 1em;
    border-radius: 4px 4px 0 0;
    background: #f4f4f4;
}

#progressive-tabs label:not(:last-of-type) {
    margin-right: 0.1em;
}

/* the checked pseudo selector is valid when a tab is selected */
#progressive-tabs input[type=radio]:checked + label {
    background: lightgrey;
}

/* support both interactions: keyboard and mouse*/
#progressive-tabs input[type=radio]:focus + label,
#progressive-tabs input[type=radio]:hover + label {
    background: #ff8c8c;
    transition: background 0.3s, color 0.3s;
    outline: 0;
    color: white;
}


#progressive-tabs input[type=radio]:focus + label {
    box-shadow: 0 0 5px 1px #5354a9;
}

/* tabpanel hidden by default*/
#progressive-tabs [role=tabpanel] {
    display: none;
    flex-basis: 100%;
    flex-grow: 1;
    order: 2;
    background: lightgrey;
    padding: 1em;
}

/*revealed when the related input radio is checked*/
#progressive-tabs input[type=radio]:checked + label + [role=tabpanel] {
    display: block;
}

Css selectors are based on semantic rather than arbitrary class names. However the use of adjacent selector forces you to use a given sequence of element in your markup. The progressive-tabs is here only to scope the style to this specific content. In practice you would use a class name or another data-attribute selector.

Using lrtiste to manage aria-states management and keyboard interaction.

If Javascript is available we give back to the script the keyboard management as well as the aria states management, which is really easy with lrtiste library

  • Markup
  • Style
  • Script

index.html


<div id="progressive-tabs" role="tablist">
  <input class="visuallyhidden" id="progressive-tab1" aria-controls="progressive-panel1" role="tab" type="radio" name="progressive-tabs"/>
  <label for="progressive-tab1">Section 1</label>
  <section id="progressive-panel1" role="tabpanel">
    <h4>header for section 1</h4>
    <p>this is a paragraph</p>
  </section>
  <input class="visuallyhidden" id="progressive-tab2" aria-controls="progressive-panel2" checked="checked" aria-selected="true" role="tab" type="radio" name="progressive-tabs"/>
  <label for="progressive-tab2">Section two</label>
  <section id="progressive-panel2" role="tabpanel">
    <h4>Header for section two</h4>
    <p>this is a paragraph for 2</p>
  </section>
  <input class="visuallyhidden" id="progressive-tab3" aria-controls="progressive-panel3" role="tab" type="radio" name="progressive-tabs"/>
  <label for="progressive-tab3">Section three</label>
  <section id="progressive-panel3" role="tabpanel">
    <h4>Header for section three</h4>
    <p>this is a paragraph for 3</p>
  </section>
</div>

The only difference is that we add a aria-selected attribute on the tab selected by default.

theme.css

/* utility class to hide visually content*/
.visuallyhidden {
    position: absolute;
    overflow: hidden;
    clip: rect(0 0 0 0);
    height: 1px;
    width: 1px;
    margin: -1px;
    padding: 0;
    border: 0;
}

#progressive-tabs[role=tablist] {
    display: flex;
    flex-wrap: wrap;
}

#progressive-tabs label {
    flex-grow: 1;
    order: 1;
    text-align: center;
    padding: 1em;
    border-radius: 4px 4px 0 0;
    background: #f4f4f4;
}

#progressive-tabs label:not(:last-of-type) {
    margin-right: 0.1em;
}

#progressive-tabs input[type=radio]:checked:not([aria-selected]) + label,
#progressive-tabs [aria-selected=true] + label {
    background: lightgrey;
}

#progressive-tabs input[type=radio]:focus:not([aria-selected]) + label,
#progressive-tabs input[type=radio]:hover + label,
#progressive-tabs [aria-selected]:focus + label {
    background: #ff8c8c;
    transition: background 0.3s, color 0.3s;
    outline: 0;
    color: white;
}

#progressive-tabs input[type=radio]:focus:not([aria-selected]) + label,
#progressive-tabs [aria-selected]:focus + label {
    box-shadow: 0 0 5px 1px #5354a9;
}

#progressive-tabs [role=tabpanel] {
    display: none;
    flex-basis: 100%;
    flex-grow: 1;
    order: 2;
    background: lightgrey;
    padding: 1em;
}

#progressive-tabs input[type=radio]:checked + label + section[role=tabpanel]:not([aria-hidden=true]),
#progressive-tabs [aria-hidden=false] {
    display: block;
}

Interestingly, here we don't need to add new style, but only add to the formerly set rules the aria specific selectors

index.js

import {tabList} from '../../../../components/tabs'; //lrtiste/components/tabs

export function bootstrap () {
  const tablistFactory = tabList();
  return tablistFactory({el: document.getElementById('progressive-tabs')});
}

The code is really simple: we only create an instance of lrtiste tablist with the appropriate HTML element.

Note: we could have composed our lrtiste with a behaviour to select by default the tab with the attribute checked (so there is no need to add the aria-selected attribute to the default tab)

The great thing with this technique is you already have the expected keyboard interaction as well as an acceptable semantic/ui-state phrasing without Javascrit (ie it will work while waiting for the script to load or if an error occurs)

Tabs as table of content strategy

The idea is to consider the tab headers as navigation link for you component (as the very same table of contents of this page).

Semantic

The tab headers would be a nothing more than a bunch of links targeting sections within our document.

We add the related aria-roles and attributes to be more accurate in our semantic. And we make sure our sections are focusable by adding a tabindex to the headers of our sections.

index.html


<div id="tabcontent-sample">
  <ul role="tablist">
    <li role="presentation"><a href="#tabcontent-sample-1" aria-selected="true" aria-controls="tabcontent-sample-1" role="tab">Section 1</a></li>
    <li role="presentation"><a href="#tabcontent-sample-2" aria-controls="tabcontent-sample-2" role="tab">Section 2</a></li>
    <li role="presentation"><a href="#tabcontent-sample-3" aria-controls="tabcontent-sample-3" role="tab">Section 3</a></li>
  </ul>
  <div id="tabcontent-sample-1" role="tabpanel">
    <h4 tabindex="0">Header for section 1</h4>
    <p>foo bar woot test blah</p>
  </div>
  <div id="tabcontent-sample-2" role="tabpanel">
    <h4 tabindex="0">Header for section 2</h4>
    <p>Another foo bar woot test blah</p>
  </div>
  <div id="tabcontent-sample-3" role="tabpanel">
    <h4 tabindex="0">Header for section 3</h4>
    <p>Yet another foo bar woot test blah</p>
  </div>
</div>

Show and hide behaviour with Javascript

Although each part of our document remain visible (even without Javascript or without css), the expected show/hide behaviour is lacking. We are going to add some script to implement the keyboard shortcuts and the aria-states management. Then we should be able to use these attributes to implement in css the show/hide features.

  • Script
  • Style

theme.css

#tabcontent-sample {
    display: flex;
    flex-wrap: wrap;
}

#tabcontent-sample [role=tablist] {
    display: flex;
    flex-grow: 1;
    flex-basis: 100%;
    padding: 0;
    margin: 0;
}

#tabcontent-sample [role=tablist] > li {
    display: flex;
    flex-grow: 1;
}

#tabcontent-sample [role=tablist] > li:not(:last-child) {
    margin-right: 0.1em;
}

#tabcontent-sample [role=tab]{
    width: 100%;
    padding: 1em;
    text-align: center;
    border-radius: 4px 4px 0 0;
    background: #f4f4f4;
    text-decoration: none;
    color: inherit;
}

#tabcontent-sample [role=tab][aria-selected=true]{
    background: lightgray;
}

/*give feedbacks to both mouse and keyboard users*/
#tabcontent-sample [role=tab]:hover,
#tabcontent-sample [role=tab]:focus{
    background: #ff8c8c;
    transition: background 0.3s, color 0.3s;
    outline: 0;
    color: white;
}

#tabcontent-sample [role=tab]:focus {
    box-shadow: 0 0 5px 1px #5354a9;
}

/* Content is visible by default until script is available and aria states taken into account*/
#tabcontent-sample [role=tabpanel] {
    flex-grow: 1;
    flex-basis: 100%;
    background: lightgray;
    padding: 1em;
}


#tabcontent-sample [role=tabpanel][aria-hidden=true] {
    display: none;
}

Again, we try to use as much as possible semantic css selectors using aria attributes.

the #tabcontent-sample css selector is just used to scope the style to the particular example, in practice you would use a more generic selector

index.js

import {tabList} from '../../../../components/tabs'; //lrtiste/components/tabs
import {compose, init} from 'stampit';

// we use stampit to compose our factories, it is not mandatory (the default Object.extend could work)
export function bootstrap () {
  const tablistFactory = compose(tabList(), init(function () {
    //not mandatory but when javascript is available we prevent the tabs as link default behaviour
    for (const tab of this.el.querySelectorAll('a[role=tab]')) {
      tab.addEventListener('click', event=>event.preventDefault());
    }
  }));

  return tablistFactory({el: document.getElementById('tabcontent-sample')});
}

We use stampit to compose our widgets with more behaviours. In this case we want to prevent the browser to follow the link related to the tab when Javascript is enabled.
